history.content:
As part of a national study examining the re-opening of research
laboratories in the U.S., a group of academics is investigating whether
a mobile app can be developed that determines air speed in indoor spaces
(i.e. research labs) using acoustic doppler shifts. Essentially, this
would allow a handful of people with mobile phones to quickly determine
areas of flow without expensive anemometers. This app will be open
source, completely free and intended as a public good. Some initial
groundwork and guidance exists but the main challenge is that this must
be working by the first week of June (!). If you have SOLID experience
with mobile apps, please email maharbiz@berkeley.edu with DOPPLER in
your subject line. Feel free to form small teams who can work together
effectively. If there is enough interest, we may setup a zoom call this
weekend to kick off.
history.subject: mobile app to measure indoor air speed (fighting covid)
